_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FIELD SOLUTIONS LLC
P.O. BOX 18
ANDALE, KANSAS 67001


For futher information contact:Joe Schauf - Operations Manager

Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Our company is an agricultural retail business who?s main focus is  providing the necessary inputs for grain production for area farmers and producers.  This company strives to maintain a safe and healthy work place.  Our owners, managers and employees have made every effort to plan the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.

The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers.

Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application for crop production nutrients.

The maximum quantity stored at this facility would be 294,600 pounds  in one 30,000  gallon and one 18,000 gallon storage tanks. In addition there are 26-1000 gallon nurse tanks with a capacity of 4400 pounds per tank making a total aggreate poundage of 411,000.

The worst case and alternate release scenarios have been evaluated and shared with our local first responders as part of an on going training program.  More importantly, our employees have been trained in their respective emergency actions, including the emergency meeting place and individual responsibilities regarding the accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.                                         
        
This company maintains and operates their NH3 plant in strict accordance with all state and local authorities.  The Kansas Department of Agriculture inspects our plant on a regular basis and we comply with their requests for improvement.  Changes or improvements in the facility?s equipment will be acted upon immediately following the enforcement agency (KDA?s) request, or as found to be necessary by our maintenance staff.

Our employees are trained in safety procedures, site specific operating procedures, plant maintenance and the employees are competency tested over the training material.  Each employee u

ses goggles and gloves during ammonia operations as well as always providing plenty of emergency safety water during nurse tank loading operations.

With the above mentioned training in mind, it makes it very easy to report that absolutely no injury accidents or property damage have occurred at this facility for the past five years.                                                                                                                 

Our emergency action plan is designed to minimize the risks to employees, the surrounding public and the area first responders this company provides plant tours for local fire department and actions plan has been shared with the county Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).  Each of our responding agencies are aware of the dangerous nature of anhydrous ammonia and they have agreed to assist us in the event of an emergency or accidental release.
